artefact: Approval of premises for civil marriage and civil partnership (England and Wales)

artefact.overview: How to get a licence to hold a civil marriage or civil partnership in your venue, and what requirements or conditions to follow
artefact.licence_short_description: Licence to hold a civil marriage or civil partnership in your venue
artefact.licence_overview:
$!Apply to your council for a licence to hold civil marriages and civil partnerships.$!

The licence will be valid for 3 years. You can apply to renew your licence if it expires in less than a year.  

##Conditions

You need to identify a specific room or rooms where weddings or civil partnerships will take place. This must be part of the building - not in the open air or under a marquee.

Your venue can't have any current or recent religious connections (eg you couldn't get a licence for a chapel in a stately home), and it must be an appropriate and dignified setting. 

You must:

- appoint someone suitable to make sure all conditions are followed if you're away
- give this person's details to the council after you get the licence
- tell the council if the person's details change
- make sure that the local registration authority or registrar has approved all wedding arrangements before ceremonies take place 
- make sure your premises can be inspected at reasonable times
- display a notice that the premises are approved 1 hour before and during ceremonies
- make sure that there's no food or drink sold or consumed in the specified area 1 hour before and during ceremonies
 
You also need to make sure that ceremonies:

- only take place in the specified area
- don't have any religious content (eg music or readings) 
- are freely open to the public

^There may also be other specific requirements for your licence (eg your council may ask you to provide space for car parking).^ 

##How to apply

Send the following to the council:

- details of yourself and your venue
- a plan of the building showing the area where ceremonies will be held
- any other documents they require, eg a copy of your public liability insurance certificate
- the licence fee (this depends on your council)

^The council will inspect the premises.^

##Penalties

If you don't follow these requirements, or if the council feels that your venue is no longer appropriate, you may lose your licence.
